title: Jack and Jay-Z mix business with friendship
text:
Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.  

Twitter founder and Jay-Z try to fit a square peg in a round hole

Why would a company that specialises in payments buy an underperforming streaming service owned by the who's who of the music world? 

That's what we were asking ourselves when Square, a financial services business founded and run by Twitter chief executive Jack Dorsey, announced it had bought a majority stake in Jay-Z's streaming platform Tidal for nearly $300m.

Square's inventors seemed just as confused, sending shares in the company down 5 per cent after the deal was announced.  

Dorsey tried to pre-empt the inevitable question on Twitter, claiming that the two companies are not all that different, which felt a little bit like trying to fit a square peg in a round hole. 

Here's how it looks to us: Dorsey and Jay-Z are friends. It's quite possible that while on a yachting trip in the Hamptons, sipping on some Ace of Spades, they came up with the idea that Square should buy Tidal. The reason? Because it can. 

Over the past year, Square's share price rose by almost 500 per cent. In 2020, revenue from sellers was $3.5bn, its “Cash App” segment, including a business that allows users to transfer money online, saw revenues of nearly $6bn. Oh, and it also made $4.6bn from bitcoin trading fees. So you can see why $300m is not much of a problem for Square.

The deal is also a coup for Jay-Z and the group of musicians who bought Tidal in 2015 for $56m. Their lofty aim to “forever change the course of music history” never materialised and Tidal has barely kept up with much bigger streaming platforms such as Spotify and Apple. 

That's because most artists' music is owned by big record labels, so it's difficult to make their songs exclusively available to Tidal. Even Jay-Z, who owns the rights to much of his musical catalogues, ultimately caved to working with competitors as Tidal struggled to draw in enough listeners. 

But there is a clear shift happening in the music industry that Dorsey may have caught on to — several big-name artists are selling their music rights. Bob Dylan last year sold his entire catalogue to Universal Music for $300m. That's one way to ensure exclusivity and a continuing income stream from artists. 

Regardless, Dorsey and Jay-Z will get to hang out much more now that the musician has been named to Square's board.

How an insurance decision triggered Greensill's unravelling

We've spent a lot of time on Greensill Capital lately — but the story is still moving fast. 

The latest huge development is that Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance has stopped making payments to the ailing finance group — a stunning schism because the links between the two have been so close that they've drawn the scrutiny of regulators. 

Catch up with the story by DD's Rob Smith and the FT's Michael Pooler and Sylvia Pfeifer here. And we've pulled together a collection of our reporting on the Greensill story here. 

One critical thing to understand in all of this is the role of insurance — the supposedly sober, even sleepy, side of finance — in triggering this week's chain of events, which the FT's Tom Braithwaite spells out here. 

In short: the reason Credit Suisse suddenly announced on Monday that it was freezing $10bn in funds linked to the company came down to a lapse in the insurance covering the credit. 

The main original insurance policy was written by The Bond & Credit Company, an Australian insurer that was acquired in 2019 by Tokio Marine. In July 2020, Tokio Marine said it would not extend or renew any Greensill policy — and that it had dismissed the underwriter in charge of the account. 

That insurance had allowed investors to treat the fund as almost risk-free. Without it, the Greensill machine was stuck. 

Greensill had spent months trying to find an alternative insurer, to no avail, court papers show. Whatever Tokio Marine's reason, its decision last summer spelt the end.

Petrobras: oil and politics

Who would want to be the chief executive of a state-controlled oil company? (Or an investor in one, for that matter.)

The head of Brazil's Petrobras recently found out exactly what a thankless task it can be when the country's rightwing president, Jair Bolsonaro, moved to replace him with an inexperienced army reserve general following a dispute over fuel price increases.

For shareholders, the abrupt ouster of Roberto Castello Branco must have stirred unpleasant memories. It didn't go down well: Petrobras' São Paulo-listed shares tumbled 20 per cent after the decision.

Petrobras gained international notoriety in the middle of the past decade for its role at the centre of a massive political corruption scheme. Uncovered by the Lava Jato (Car Wash) investigation, the scandal rocked the country and led to the arrest of former presidents. 

But arguably, just as harmful was the political meddling under former leftwing leader Dilma Rousseff, who forced the oil producer to slash fuel prices in a bid to tame inflation — interference that cost the group $40bn, according to Castello Branco.

With the government controlling 50.5 per cent of Petrobras voting rights with just 36.8 per of the company's shares, a serious concern for minority shareholders is whether the oil group will stick to its policy of setting fuel prices in line with international rates. 

As Bolsonaro gears up for a re-election bid next year, he is under pressure from the powerful truckers' lobby amid rising living costs. The fear will be that this episode could be a harbinger of further populist interventionism in the economy.

The former army captain's administration has nevertheless insisted it is pressing ahead with promised structural reforms to kickstart Latin America's largest economy. A key plank is the privatisation of large state-controlled entities, including power generator Eletrobras.

Prospective investors please form an orderly queue . . . 

Job moves

  • Linklaters has promoted capital markets partner Hwang Hwa Sim to global head of the practice. He will succeed Michael Voisin, whose tenure ends in April. The firm also hired former head of the UK government legal service Sir Jonathan Jones as a senior consultant within its dispute resolution practice in London.

  • Orrick added Marsha Mogilevich as a partner in its capital markets practice in New York. She joins from Kirkland & Ellis.

  • Allen & Overy has acquired Akin Gump's renewables practice, which will be co-led by existing A&O partners Dan Sinaiko, John Marciano and Akin alumni Greg Lavigne, Matthew Nesburn, Andrea Wang Lucan and Sam Kamyans. As part of the expansion, A&O will open a West Coast office in Los Angeles.

  • Ropes & Gray has hired Emily Brown as a partner in its asset management group. She will join the London office in April from Schulte Roth & Zabel. 

  • Partners Group nominated Joseph Landy, former co-chief executive of Warburg Pincus, for election as a new independent member of its board. Additionally, vice-chairman Eric Strutz, will retire from the board in May as his term nears expiration. The board has proposed to appoint existing board member Martin Strobel in his place.
